The multitude of Letters that I receive; the irresistible temptation which like the tide current of the Bay of Fundy imperceptibly urges me upon the breakers of every debate that arises in the house, and the disablement of my hand to write with despatch, crowd me to despatch— I received this morning from my Son a Letter noticing a gross blunder in the Resolves of the Legislature of Massachusetts, now referred to a select Committee, and for which I knew not how to account; and which it will be difficult to correct.— This morning at 10. I went to the Capitol to meet the Committee on the revisal of the rules— Only four members of the Committee met—Adams, Beardsley, C. J. Ingersoll and Vinton—no Quorum— Nevertheless, we proceeded to compare the copy made in the clerk’s office under French’s direction, of the Rules revised by the Committee with the copy on which the amendments agreed upon by them were minuted down, and we found some errors to be connected, and some rules requiring further revisal.— We adjourned to next Tuesday morning at 10, hoping that we shall then have a Quorum.— I have some concern about the manner of printing the report— The discussion in the house will be difficult and perplexed, unless the existing rules should be printed in parallel pages with the proposed revisal; and if they are, the chances are that the only important amendment made by the Committee, the exclusion of the gag-rule will not be adopted by the house; or be replaced by the substitute moved by Chapman ten times worse than the existing rule.— This I have no doubt is Wise’s real purpose, and that his solemn parade of renouncing all opposition to the reception of abolition petitions was a cheat— I borrowed in the Library, Roses Orlando Inamorato and Furioso, and found his sword Durindana in both of them— In the Law Library I borrowed the first Volume of a digest of the Pennsylvania Laws, containing the first Act of the Legislature of that State to abolish Slavery. I met Mr Giddings there and he gave me the document containing the report of the Secretary of War— I stop’d at the general Post Office, and gave the Postmaster General a Letter from Harley Sergeant, once a postmaster at Butternuts, New-York to Mr Tyson second assistant Postmaster General, now absent at Philadelphia— Mr Wickliffe said the Letter should be attended to

With Isaac Hull Adams, and my granddaughter Mary-Louisa, I attended the morning public worship in the Hall of the House of Representatives. The Prayer was made and the hymn read, and by two lines at a time sung by Mr Tustin the chaplain to the Senate The Sermon was preached by the Revd. Mr Bacon, now President of the Columbian College, from John 12.32. “And I, if I be lifted up from the earth, will draw all men unto me”— An edifying, but not very eloquent discourse— It was short—the whole service occupying not more than an hour— The Seats of the members were generally filled; though very few of them by themselves— We walked home with a bright Sun, a clear sky, and a frosty, but kindly Northwester.— After dinner at the second Presbyterian church, the Revd. James Knox preached from Ecclesiastes 3.15. the latter part of the verse— [“]And God required that which is past”— There is something obscure in the meaning of this sentence— It is in the chapter which teaches that to every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven— The meaning of the passage is that God repeats the past or in other words that there is nothing new under the Sun— Mr Knox discoursed upon it, as if it had been, God shall call men to account for that which is past, and made of it a fervid and minatory exhortation to repentance—a Subject never more appropriate than at the close of the year— The exhortation to repentance is indeed always in season, and the episcopal prayer book by prescribing it as a perpetual prayer, takes for granted that it is always needed and never effected. Always the same general confession of enormous sins, and prayer for pardon— Always the same promise of absolution upon true repentance and belief in the gospel— Do they not thus become mere forms of words, without meaning? And is the eternal scolding of a presbyterian preacher more efficacious to work out repentance or absolution? We had evening visits from General and Mrs Jesup—Dr Frye, Walter Hellen and Richard Cutts. I closed the year quietly in my writing chamber, grateful for the past— Praying for the future.

Day. My purposed hour of rising is four. But faltering health breaks in upon the time, and I am seldom up till near six— An hour to make my fire, wash and dress— Two hours to journalize— Breakfast.— At Committee and the house from home ten till 4. home and dine at 5— Siesta— Read, write, and muse till 10— 11.— 12 and to bed.
